title: 110_hr1796
content: The Act is known as the "National Emergency Centers Establishment Act" and it establishes National Emergency Centers. The National Emergency Centers Establishment Act mandates the creation of at least 6 national emergency centers on military installations. These centers will provide temporary housing, medical assistance, training for first responders, and coordination of preparedness efforts during emergencies or disasters. Other needs may also be addressed as determined by the Secretary of Homeland Security. The National Emergency Centers Establishment Act mandates the creation of at least 6 national emergency centers on military installations to provide temporary housing, medical assistance, training for first responders, and coordination of preparedness efforts during emergencies or disasters. Other appropriate needs may also be addressed as determined by the Secretary of Homeland Security. The National Emergency Centers Establishment Act requires the designation of military installations as national emergency centers. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Secretary of Defense, must designate at least 6 military installations as national emergency centers within 60 days of the Act's enactment. These centers must be capable of meeting the needs of individuals affected by emergencies, be environmentally safe, and able to scale up or down for disaster drills and operations. The national emergency centers must be capable of disaster preparedness and response drills, housing permanent structures, hosting necessary infrastructure, and consisting of a complete operations command center with state-of-the-art facilities. They should also be easily accessible and able to facilitate handicapped and medical facilities. National emergency centers must be established in specific areas to facilitate handicapped and medical facilities during emergencies or disasters. Preference is given to closed military installations for designation. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Secretary of Defense, prefers closed military installations as sites for national emergency centers. If there are not enough closed military installations meeting requirements, portions of existing military installations can be designated. The Secretary of Defense must transfer administrative jurisdiction to the Secretary of Homeland Security within 180 days of designation. The Secretary of Homeland Security and the Secretary of Defense must enter into a cooperative agreement for the establishment of a national emergency center within 180 days of designation. A report outlining the reasons for selecting each designated site must be submitted to Congress within 90 days of the enactment of the Act. The report must outline reasons for site selection, infrastructure needs, environmental cleanup, transfer of control, and plans for a national emergency center. The Secretary of Homeland Security must update the report within 120 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Homeland Security, with the Secretary of Defense, must submit a report to Congress for each designated site, including updates, progress on control transfer, cooperative agreements for a national emergency center, and recommendations for necessary authorizations and appropriations. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in collaboration with the Secretary of Defense, is required to submit a final report to Congress within one year of the enactment of the Act. The report should include details on the transfer of control, cooperative agreements, and any other relevant information for the establishment of a national emergency center at designated sites. Additionally, the Secretary of Homeland Security may need to provide additional reports as necessary. The Secretary of Homeland Security, with the Secretary of Defense, must submit a final report to Congress within a year of the Act's enactment. Additional reports may be submitted as needed to update on progress meeting the Act's requirements. SEC. 4. LIMITATIONS ON STATUTORY CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not affect the authority of the Federal Government to provide emergency or disaster assistance, or the authority of State or local governments to respond to emergencies. SEC. 5. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $180,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2008 and 2009 to carry out this Act. Such funds shall remain available until expended. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "closed military installation" refers to a military installation approved for closure or realignment under the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Act of 1990, meeting specific requirements. The term "emergency" is defined as per the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act. The Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act defines "major disaster" and "military installation" according to specific criteria.
